author: albert.feghaly
title: Evidence-Based Knowledge Aggregator
description: Ответы на вопросы о жизни и Вселенной даются после утомительного процесса накопления знаний и бесчисленных часов изучения литературы.

f6_assessments.q0:
Interesting idea. I am not sure it is tractable. In the end though this proposal is basically asking for $500 to write a proposal. Whilst its a tiny request, I am not sure this is the sort of thing we want to fund. On a wider note, Catalyst may well spend that much just compensating CA's and vCA's to review this proposal. I don't think we should be funding people to write up proposals, this process is to fund good proposals, not ideas which could lead to good proposals.
I would suggest just writing up the proposal and submitting it that for funding to deliver something concrete
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan is just to write a proposal. However given the nature of the problem its not clear a proposal can be written to solve it. The proposers advisor has already steered him away from doing it.
If you wish to work on this, please instead write up a proposal on what you would do, not seek funding to write the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
All that had been proposed to be delivered is a proposal. We cannot audit progress. We could obviously audit the delivery of a proposal. But success would be delivery of a proposal that could then be built into a project which could be delivered. 
How would you measure success? What would be failure, delivery of a proposal which cannot actually be implemented?

f6_assessments.q0: Current hypothetical research is based on probability. Bundling a maximal potential of data to calculate the highest probable outcome could create a shortcut in current day research. It is still dependant on probability, but the chance that it would process more data than its human counterparts are significantly higher. The introduction of percentages on a binary outcome is a good idea as it still leaves room for nuances when the outcome cannot be handled as a simple positive or negative output. While this might provide a useful tool, it still relies on human interaction to determine its verifiability.
f6_assessments.q1: This project has been postponed. Instead of withdrawing the proposal, the proposing team has opted to leave it open to provide the community an opportunity to contact them in terms of possible collaborations and to communicate this idea on a larger scale. The requested budget corresponds with the time invested to write out the proposal, although this creates doubts wether the writing of a funding request should be incentivised or not. For these reasons, the team's relevant experience is not included in this assessment for the time being.
f6_assessments.q2: The website is centered around another project the team is currently involved with. So to be relevant to this particular proposal, it can only be used as a means of confirming relevant experience. As the project has been put on hold, there has not been much detailed information provided yet except for an initial plan outlay. Looking forward to the evolution of this proposal next fund when the team will probably have found the people it needs as a result from reaching out in this creative way.

f6_assessments.q0: An Intriguing proposal, but I can't help but wonder if this would solve the dogmatic views. By adding a percentage based on a yes or no question you still leave room for skepticism. People would be tempted to question the verifiability of the system. And this doesn't even begin questioning the amounts of data that would have to be available for this project since the proposers are proposing one system to answer all questions in life.
f6_assessments.q1: As stated above this was the idea behind the proposal, since reading through the proposal I was beginning to wonder if the proposer would have time for this because he is involved in another massive proposal. I was happy to see that in the end, we came to the conclusion that the proposal is postponed but not excluded. The proposer suggests writing his proposal in full detail so that everyone has access to it. Given this I have to remain neutral because I don't if this is acceptable or not.
f6_assessments.q2: As stated above I am in conflict about this proposal. The execution of the proposal is not in-line with what the proposer is suggesting. The fact that the proposer has post-pone the project since he needs to focus on the main project, I can't help but wonder why suggesting to write done a description at an hourly rate of $50. This is a contradict to its own.

f6_assessments.q0:
I do not think it is appropriate for a proposal to be effectively abandoned, and instead take CA time to assess a $500 proposal to write a proposal. It would not be good for Project Catalyst if this becomes a widespread practice.

With respect to the substance of the underlying proposal, it articulates a big problem related to AI. However, the proposed system would be extremely complex to deliver and is beyond the capabilities of current AI methods. It might be possible to do some of this with large pre-trained language models like GPT-3, but turning any generic question into a tree of yes-no questions would involve many further steps.

In addition, this proposal does not articulate any connection with SingularityNet.
f6_assessments.q1:
My comments relate to the underlying proposal, rather than the $500 report project. I might give a higher rating if/when this is resubmitted as a proper proposal.

I do not believe that the team here has the capability to build the system described. The best AI minds in the world have not been able to build a system like this, and there is no explanation why this team would be able to do so. That is said without disrespect to the team, who seem to have an interesting variety of capabilities.

The proposal also contains a reference to smart contracts, which have little apparent relevance to solving the problem presented.
f6_assessments.q2:
My comments relate to the underlying proposal, rather than the $500 report project. I might give a higher rating if/when this is resubmitted as a proper proposal.

The proposal contains no criteria allowing for auditability.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal suggests a knowledge network that can be used to better understand the data and reasoning behind certain knowledge. Instead of providing a yes or no response the aim of the proposer system would be to give more depth to what questions must be answered for the original question answer to be clear. 

The team has postponed this proposal in the short term, if it was clearly defined and how it will be executed then this could be explored again in the future by the community.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has provided team information all with LinkedIn profiles that show the background of those involved. The proposal states it is only himself that is creating the proposal and that they aren't focussing on this at this time. Instead of the project a small technical specification task has been added costing $500. It is unclear whether the proposal team want this funded or instead that the project is properly postponed.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal presents an interesting topic area however has little clarity due to not diving deeper into what will be achieved. No KPIs or success objectives were given nor any milestones. The proposal team stated this proposal is postponed at the moment so if they revisit this they can add that information and resubmit the project.

solution: Система, в которой самостоятельные вопросы связаны между собой в рамках массивной сети знаний, развивающейся внутри децентрализованного мозга.
experience:
Биоинформатика, Python, JS, Big Data, ML, AI, Blockchain.  
Команда = 5 + 3 советника -> https://intellart.ca/#/team
Уровень PhD, уровень Post-doc.
